media.caption: Claudia explains why people develop binge eating habits.
Listen to Alex talk about how he felt when he first started treatment.

columns:
1. Before a binge

Did something happen to upset you? Were you feeling overwhelmed by emotion?

2. During a binge

Did you feel as though you had lost all control?

3. After a binge

Were you feeling ashamed or embarassed? Did you do something to make up for the binge?

leaves.text: Events, situations or emotions can trigger binge eating. You may find it difficult to identify these at first however we know from experience that there will always be a trigger. Throughout the program we will help you to identify your triggers and work upon better controlling them.
We can generally categorise triggers into four main groups:
1. Biological Triggers
e.g. dieting, restricting food intake
2. Food & Eating Triggers
e.g. feeling full, breaking a food rule
3. Body Image Triggers
e.g. gaining weight, feeling fat, wearing tight clothes
4. Mood/Emotional Triggers
e.g. feeling angry, sad, anxious or lonely
We will learn more about these in future sessions.
Binge eating can take many shapes and forms. Generally, however, the foods eaten during a binge are those that the person is trying to avoid, otherwise known as "forbidden foods".

Once you start to overeat it can often be very difficult to stop, leaving you feeling hopeless and out of control. You might feel so compelled and driven to eat that you begin to act in ways that you see as different to who you are and how you behave normally.

Binge eating and overeating can bring about feelings of shame and embarrassment, meaning that it becomes something you try to do in secret. For example, eating in your bedroom or waiting until you are home alone. Having no one else know about your binges can make it even more difficult to stop.

media.caption: Claudia explains the vicious cycle of binge eating and how it is maintained.

leaves.text: As you can see from the cognitive behaviour therapy (CBT) model of the cycle of binge eating below there are many things that drive the overeating cycle including negative feelings, trying to be good or skip food, hunger, fear of weight gain, and they all feed into each other. Have a close look at the cycle and see if you recognise it.
Together, let's build the vicious cycle of binge eating by reviewing the three stages of a binge which we spoke about earlier.
1. Before a binge
Several triggers can lead you to have an urge to binge, including:

2. During a binge
After this you may lose control and find yourself in a binge or overeat.
2. After a binge
You may feel guilty or fear that you will gain weight. Because of this you may do things to compensate for the foods you've eaten.
These behaviours serve to worsen the shame and negative feelings you have about yourself.

Together, let's build the vicious cycle of binge eating by reviewing the three stages of a binge which we spoke about earlier.
1. Before a binge
Several triggers can lead you to have an urge to binge, including:
2. During a binge
After this you may lose control and find yourself in a binge or overeat.
2. After a binge
You may feel guilty or fear that you will gain weight. Because of this you may do things to compensate for the foods you've eaten.
These behaviours serve to worsen the shame and negative feelings you have about yourself.
To cope with these feelings and prevent weight gain you may slip back into a pattern of food restriction, which again makes you susceptible to common triggers.
Overall, the behaviours you engage in after a binge continue the cycle as you become more reliant on ways to undo the binge and less likely to stop yourself from starting the binge itself.
